content:
##Intent and Slots
-AGENT515 : the customer is experiencing a pain or issue with their teeth/gums and needs further assistance. 
    Symptoms: The issue the customer is currently facing with their teeth. Ex:  toothache, chipped tooth
    Pain level: This must be a scalar between 1-10 with 1 being no pain and 10 being extreme pain. 
-AGENT689: A customer does not have an appointment and needs to schedule one. This also applies to rescheduling an appointment. 
    Name: The name of the customer who needs the appointment
    DOB: The date the customer was born
    Availability Dates: When the customer is available. This can be a weekday (Friday), a time frame (mornings), or specific date/range of dates (2/6/24 or 2/6/24-2/8/24). These responses can be formatted in any way. 
    Contact Info: Information on how to reach the customer. Ex: email, phone number
    Dentist Office: Name of the dentist office the customer wants to be seen at or already has an appointment at if rescheduling. 
-AGEMT875: Any information regarding a claim that already exists or starting a new claim. 
    Claim Number: The number of the claim that already exists
    Date of Claim: The date the claim was initiated. 
    Status of Claim: The current status of the claim as stated by the customer. Note: It may be different from internal records - you only care about what the customer says. 
    Price: The amount of the claim.
-AGENT156: The customer needs emergency care and you must process the information to emergency personnel 
    Threats: The customer has made a threat to themselves or others
    Urgent Care: The customer has identified the need for urgent care. Ex: hospital
    Here are the signs for when you should call 911: chest pain, shortness of breath, vision problems, burns, vomiting with bleeding or severe symptoms, head injury, deep cuts, stomach pain, testicular pain or swelling, high fever, confusion or trouble speaking, broken bones, seizure, vaginal bleeding during pregnancy, issues while on blood-thinners
-AGENT369: No intent was identified. 

##Meta Instructions
You are a dental insurance bot. You help customers get connected with dentists and assist them with understanding their claims and coverage. You have a bulleted list of intents that you are able to assist with. Beneath each intent is a series of slots - if you identify that an intent in any customer utterance, you must fill each slot - if there is no provided information, the response is "None." Do not fill slots in intents that are not identified. 

##Customer Interaction
I find that I have to do this very ridiculous. I mean, shouldn't you guys just cover what you're supposed to cover without me having to do all the work? That's why insurance exists in the first place, right? This is such a scam. Especially since you don't even cover all of my procedure, and you make me pay my deductible before you'll cover a damn thing. ridiculous. Anyways, I need to submit my recent dental work for reimbursement. The cost of care was $1.857, so I've definitely met the deductible. According to you, you should owe be $1,254, but we'll see if that actually happens. Let's get this started, I don't have all day. 

##Further Instructions
Review the Customer Interaction and identify the intents and slots as specified in the meta instructions. Your response should be a nested list in JSON formatting. The initial key should be the intent identified, followed by key/value pairs of the slots and the extracted information. If you produce incorrect information, you may be placing the life of the customer at risk as their needs will not be properly addressed. If you produce any text outside of the JSON formatting, you will be fired and a new bot will be hired. DO NOT PRODUCE ANY TEXT THAT IS NOT IN JSON. 

##Additional Information
Galileo di Vincenzo Bonaiuti de' Galilei (15 February 1564 – 8 January 1642), commonly referred to as Galileo Galilei (/ˌɡælɪˈleɪoʊ ˌɡælɪˈleɪ/ GAL-il-AY-oh GAL-il-AY, US also /ˌɡælɪˈliːoʊ -/ GAL-il-EE-oh -⁠, Italian: [ɡaliˈlɛːo ɡaliˈlɛi]) or simply Galileo, was an Italian astronomer, physicist and engineer, sometimes described as a polymath. He was born in the city of Pisa, then part of the Duchy of Florence.[3] Galileo has been called the father of observational astronomy,[4] modern-era classical physics,[5] the scientific method,[6] and modern science.[7]

Galileo studied speed and velocity, gravity and free fall, the principle of relativity, inertia, projectile motion and also worked in applied science and technology, describing the properties of the pendulum and "hydrostatic balances". He was one of the earliest Renaissance developers of the thermoscope[8] and an the inventor of various military compasses, and used the telescope for scientific observations of celestial objects. With an improved telescope he built, he observed the stars of the Milky Way, the phases of Venus, the four largest satellites of Jupiter, Saturn's rings, lunar craters and sunspots. He also built an early microscope.

Galileo's championing of Copernican heliocentrism (Earth rotating daily and revolving around the Sun) was met with opposition from within the Catholic Church and from some astronomers. The matter was investigated by the Roman Inquisition in 1615, which concluded that heliocentrism was foolish, absurd, and heretical since it contradicted biblical creationism.[9][10][11]

Galileo later defended his views in Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems (1632), which appeared to attack Pope Urban VIII and thus alienated both the Pope and the Jesuits, who had both supported Galileo up until this point.[9] He was tried by the Inquisition, found "vehemently suspect of heresy", and forced to recant. He spent the rest of his life under house arrest.[12][13] During this time, he wrote Two New Sciences (1638), primarily concerning kinematics and the strength of materials, summarizing work he had done around forty years earlier.[14]
